Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 02:20AM NSWTD wrote: This post reminds me of a column I read from Ms. Manners......she suggested when someone was asking a question too personal for you to what to answer to look them straight in the eye and say....."now, why would you want to know that?"   I have used that response, always with a smile, then change the topic.  I have NEVER had anyone ask me twice.   Now, the snotty side of me might like to answer a question of "so, how is your prognosis" with something such as......."I expect to die to tomorrow"......but that would be too rude now wouldn't it?
Posts.Title: "So....what's your prognosis?" (Insert sad look here) heathermcd anonymice

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2010 05:26PM NSWTD wrote: First let me say that I have absolutely nothing against raising money for BC research or any worth while cause....but on the flip side...I really cannot stand all the pink ribbon stuff.  Should anyone really buy the pink Kitchenaid Mixer just because X amount of the purchase price is going to support BC?   Me, I am going to buy the color that best coordinates with my kitchen.   And, if that is pink,,....great.  I have not purchased one single pink thing since my diagnosis and do not plan on doing so.   Maybe I just do not want a constant reminder of that dreaded day.    Best to all
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 11:35AM NSWTD wrote: Great ! Glad to hear about the outcome.  Keep getting screened.  I had microcalcs and did have wide spread DCIS and had unimast to deal with it.    In seeking a BC related org to volunteer, my only advise is to seek out how much goes to BC research/treatment/etc and how much is tagged for admin/overhead costs.  You want a reputable org where the majority of the dollars goes to the primary cause, not the admin costs.    Good luck

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 03:30PM NSWTD wrote: Maybe, maybe he needs a support group too?   He has stress in all of this.   I am not saying he is an angel, just that he may need more help than he is letting on.  On the flip side, better to find out someone's true colors sooner rather than later.    Best of luck in your treatment.  Take care
Posts.Title: relationship will not survive timerdog alamik

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2010 10:19AM NSWTD wrote: If you are comfortable with the credentials of both docs, go with the one you most connect with.  I saw one gen surgeon, I think I freaked him out.....saw a second team (BC doc and PS) and liked both of them tremendously...but had an appt already set at the University of Chicago team so went.  Both docs really impressed me and made me feel so at ease.   Both were like me, straight forward but with compassion.  I am going forward with the docs at UCMC.... You will know who you want to have operate on you and if you do not, perhaps another opinion is in order.   Good luck
Posts.Title: How to choose a doctor dsj dsj

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 09:15PM NSWTD wrote: I am sorry you have to deal with this.   I do not have much advice, other than it sounds like you have prepared good responses to annoying questions.  Good for you for being prepared!  Maybe just say, I am having a "no talk about cancer day" - and change the subject.      I opted to tell very few of my diagnosis or treatment and there are times I feel bad I left people out of the know......but then when I hear of others having trouble, I am glad I made the decision I did.   Best of luck to you and know that, in time, you will not be their topic of conversation and everyone will have moved on.
Posts.Title: How do you deal with all the questions? Canchaser TexasKaren

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2010 08:07PM NSWTD wrote: Heck, even my PS says you are best to select someone you like 'cause you are going to see me at least once a year.   I had an SIEA flap (similar to DIEP) and to tell you the truth I am happy to have it monitored....and who knows....I am 54....maybe seeing a PS every year may prompt me to have something I would like to have worked on done...... :)
Posts.Title: Follow up with surgeon for 5 years? Why? Halah Mantra

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 03:35AM NSWTD wrote: I kept a notebook of various things I needed for doc appts like list of all current meds, others docs names/addresses/numbers, insurance info, etc. And I kept a small notebook for all my questions and their answers.  I typically carried only what I needed to various appts. I used a simple tote bag and added a luggage tag with all my info on it (name, address, cell phone) in the event I left this bag somewhere along my path for the day.  I never did forget it, but if I had and someone could not have quickly identified me, it would have meant so much more stress for me.    Thanks for all the other great ideas.

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 09:50PM NSWTD wrote: I am not in the insurance business but have heard that a first time or even second time denial is not uncommon. I would keep appealing and maybe even find myself a lawyer.   Sometimes it may be a tactic by the entity to deny coverage and the denied individual may not appeal, saving them money.
Posts.Title: help!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! helpkellyheal NSWTD

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 11:55AM NSWTD wrote: I used Merdema on a scar on my hand when I had a skin cancer removed. I can barely tell where I had it done now and it is about 1.5 inches long.  I asked my PS about these products after my mast and he didn't think they worked.  He suggested just plain old A&D ointment, so I have been using that.   I still have to have my refinement surgery after my recon, so I may alternate between A&D and Mederma.     I have also read about vitamin E capsules, much like the wheat germ oil capsules.

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 02:37PM NSWTD wrote: I had a uni March 2 with immediate recon...I am extremely happy with my new breast and glad I kept my real one too.   My PS is so great, with a tank top on you cannot tell a thing.  The size,drape, shape, everything looks great.  If I should be so unfortunate to have a cancer occur in the healthy breast down the road, I know I can deal with it. They surgery was not bad at all and recovery has been easier than expected.  Best of luck to you.....you are strong and you will be fine.
Posts.Title: Calling all uni-mast ladies 1marmalade1 Brendatrue

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 09:49PM NSWTD wrote: I am well insured and have FT employment at the time, so at the moment we are ok, however my DH has have three periods of unemployment due to his workplaces going bankrupt....we live in Michigan and he works for auto suppliers.    We have..... stopped going out to eat, make things from scratch from home sold things at garage sales and consignment shops, also Craigslist  got rid of land line and only have our cell phones cut back on cable channels (haven't been able to break the cord on this totally)  shop at consignment stores and good will  buy much more real food, it really is cheaper  keep the house cooler in winter, warmer in summer  turn off lights when we leave a room  try not to buy anything we do not absolutely need  Good luck to all
Posts.Title: The sensitive subject Bernicky mrsnjband

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 06:22PM NSWTD wrote: pejkug3, Been there, done that.   I know it is exhausting trying to just get started.   I was so fortunate, my hubby did a ton of research for me, he even made doc appts for me.   I interviewed two teams and ended up the university of Chicago.   Please consider a university hospital if you have one near.  Many times they are up on current techniques and treatments and have a very good "team" approach already in place.  This eases things on you so you do not have to worry about all your docs working well together.
Posts.Title: Tired...I want off this ride... pejkug3 NSWTD

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 08:12PM NSWTD wrote: Very sorry to hear of your diagnosis.  I think we are turned upside down when we first hear.   I thought I would die of a heart attack before I could get my treatment figured out.   By, here I am almost 12 months to the day of my mastectomy......feeling good and finishing up my recon.   Hang in there, you will make it.  And, we will be here to listen and support as much as we can.
Posts.Title: starting to freak out djls SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 05:06PM NSWTD wrote: I had a unimat last March.  Recovering nicely.  Just had some tattooing done last week.   I was sort of mixed on getting a fake nipple, but now think that I will.   I was definitely ok with the tattooing, but I think I want a little protusion there like the other side.  I was so sad last March headed into my surgery.  I just was not confident how things would turn out.  Ended up ok.  The results are amazing. I did have immediate recon, SIEA (similar to DIEP).  I have so few scars it is amazing.   I feel pretty much the same too.   And, heck I got a tummy tuck out of the deal....woo hoo !!  Hang in there, I will say a prayer for all (if you pray).   It is sooooo much better once you are on the other side of surgery.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 09:40PM NSWTD wrote: OMG LOL......I was thinking of this and then thought better of it.   I hope you thoroughly enjoyed it and it was therapuetic as well.
Posts.Title: Bye Bye Boobie party TerriD jeaniept

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 02:01PM - edited May 8, 2010 02:02PM by NSWTD I had three drains, but luckily only went home with 2 of them. I had a SIEA flap immediately so one drain on right side of foob and one in abs.   I have a walk in shower and home and stool to sit on. My drains were so long that I sat on the stool and just placed them on the floor while I showered.  It worked great.   When I was wearing clothes, I just pinned them to the bottom of my camisole. With yoga pants on, I would just roll up the tubes and place the bulbs into my panties and with a big shirt over it, you could not tell a thing. To me having them hang on a string around one's neck sounds uncomfortable. But, different things work for different people.  Also, since I knew the drain and I would not be "married" for long, the less effort I put into them, the better.  I should think a couple of good sized safety pins should do the trick.
Posts.Title: I got my date...May 17 bmx..and now I have weird questions... 1WonderWoman Sherry9316

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 09:18PM NSWTD wrote: Everyone is so individual.  My hubby's aunt had mastectomy at age 80, no other treatment, and is now 89 and has no problems.  Her opion....take it out and be done with it....she did not want chemo or rads.....and is happy with that decision.  Me, if I were 90....maybe if healthy would also opt for mast....then just let me live my life in peace.
Posts.Title: 90 year old just diagnosed wontonsnowy lago

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 01:41PM NSWTD wrote: I had a right only mastectomy with immediate reconstruction...SIEA or SEIA (can never remember which) .   I was VERY sensitive in the entire recon area for about 2 weeks. It even hurt to have the docs put the stethascope (sp?) on my chest while I was in the hosp.   I did have short shooting pains for about 6 weeks, those have subsided some.  My PS says that the short shooting pains are likely my nerves trying to find a new path.  The nurse told me to massage around the area when I am in the shower. She said it may help the nerves find their way.   I had a skin sparing mast, not sure if that makes a difference.   The area under my arm is a little numb but getting better every day.  I was told some will get some feeling back and others may not, and even if one does, there are varying degrees of feeling.     I only had sentinal node removed, so not a lot of disruption there.   I am VERY happy with my results. I go back in July for next appt to discuss the enhancement step, although the PS did such a great job, that surgery should be a cake walk.  I can even wear tank tops now and I cannot tell I had any surgery when I look in the mirror.   The size, drape, position is almost identical to my left breast.    Good luck to you....
Posts.Title: numbness at surgery site Laurie_R Laurie_R

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 07:14PM NSWTD wrote: I had DCIS in only one breast and thought about 1 day of having bilat mx....I did not choose that route and now am glad I did not. I have one real boob and one foob....the foob looks amazingly like my real one.  for me to take healthy tissue and destroy it was not of my making.   I would only have done both if my life were at risk and today it is not.     But, if you search around these boards, there are a lot of women who opted to take them both.   It is really a very personal decision and no one here can help you other than to share and listen.    Best of luck whatever you do.
Posts.Title: decision, decisions lovesnature NSWTD

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 06:38PM NSWTD wrote: At most chain drug stores they sell a gauze that is treated with vaseline...I cannot recall the name of it, but it is not too expensive and it will not stick to your skin.  I would try that then can you wrap an ace bandage around you, tight enough to hold everything in place, but loose enough to not hurt you?
